To create interdependence in coal and steel so that one country could no longer mobilise its armed forces without others knowing.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Single European Act?

answers.label: To reform the institutions in preparation for Portugal and Spain's membership and speed up decision-making in preparation for the single market.
To extend European integration to include general economic cooperation.
To create interdependence in coal and steel so that one country could no longer mobilise its armed forces without others knowing.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Treaty on the European Union / the Maastricht Treaty?

answers.label: To prepare for European Monetary Union and introduce elements of a political union (citizenship, common foreign and internal affairs policy).
To create a single Commission and a single Council to serve the then three European Communities (EEC, Euratom, ECSC).
To reform the EU institutions in preparation for the arrival of future member countries.
To reform the institutions so that the EU could function efficiently after reaching 25 member countries

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Treaty of Amsterdam?

answers.label: To reform the EU institutions in preparation for the arrival of future member countries.
To reform the institutions so that the EU could function efficiently after reaching 25 member countries
To make the EU more democratic, more efficient and better able to address global problems, such as climate change, with one voice
To prepare for European Monetary Union and introduce elements of a political union (citizenship, common foreign and internal affairs policy).

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Treaty of Nice?

answers.label: To reform the institutions so that the EU could function efficiently after reaching 25 member countries
To make the EU more democratic, more efficient and better able to address global problems, such as climate change, with one voice
To reform the EU institutions in preparation for the arrival of future member countries.

To establish the European Union and introduce the co-decision procedure, giving Parliament more say in decision-making, and creating new forms of cooperation between EU governments (e.g., on defence and justice and home affairs).

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Treaty of Lisbon?

answers.label: To make the EU more democratic, more efficient and better able to address global problems, such as climate change, with one voice
To reform the EU institutions in preparation for the arrival of future member countries.

To establish the European Union and introduce the co-decision procedure, giving Parliament more say in decision-making, and creating new forms of cooperation between EU governments (e.g., on defence and justice and home affairs).
To reform the institutions so that the EU could function efficiently after reaching 25 member countries

answers.label: More power for the European Parliament (and clarification which powers belong to the EU, MS or both), change of voting procedures in the Council, citizens' initiative, a permanent president of the Council of the European Union, a new High Representative for Foreign Affairs, a new EU diplomatic service.
Introduce methods for changing the composition of the Commission and redefining the voting system in the Council.
Amending, renumbering and consolidating EU and EEC treaties. More transparent decision-making

The extension of qualified majority voting in the Council (making it harder for a single country to veto proposed legislation), creation of the cooperation and assent procedures, giving Parliament more influence.

answers.label: Manages EU policies and allocates EU funding
Adopts and amends legislative proposals
Decides on the EU's foreign and security policies
Decides on the political direction of the EU and adopts the EU budget

questions.question: Which of the following is the EU’s independent executive arm?

answers.label: The European Commission
The European Parliament
The Council of the EU
The Court of Justice of the EU

questions.question: Who decides on the European Commission’s internal organisation and assigns portfolios to Commissioners?

answers.label: The EU Commission President
Member States
The European Parliament President
The President of the Council

questions.question: According to the EU Commission’s rules of procedure, which of the following are the types of internal decision-making procedures?

answers.label: Oral, written, empowerment, and delegation procedures
Delegation and implementation procedures
Regular and exceptional procedures
Oral and written procedures, and special case procedures

questions.question: What was the effect of the United Kingdom’s withdrawal from the EU on the number of seats in the EU Parliament?

answers.label: The total seats were decreased to 705, with some member states gaining seats
The UK’s 73 seats were redistributed evenly amongst member states, maintaining the total of 750 seats
There was no change, there are still currently 750 seats
The 73 British MEPs’ seats were eliminated, leaving 677 seats in total

questions.question: What is REACT-EU?

answers.label: Recovery Assistance for Cohesion and the Territories of Europe, an initiative delivered through the Coronavirus Response Investment Initiative
REACTion to the COVID Pandemic from the EU, an initiative delivered through the Coronavirus Response Investment Initiative
REACTion to the COVID Pandemic from the EU, a programme for specific regions especially affected by the pandemic
Health Emergency Preparedness and Reaction, an EU Commission department to prevent, detect, and rapidly respond to health emergencies

questions.question: How is the number of MEPs per member state calculated?

answers.label: By degressive proportionality: no country can have fewer than 6 or more than 96 MEPs
It is a first-past-the-post electoral system (FPTP or FPP)
It depends on the European election results in each Member State, and small countries always have 5 MEPs to ensure representation
Proportionally to the country’s population size, plus one MEP for large countries

questions.question: Where is the official seat of the EU Parliament?

answers.label: Strasbourg
Strasbourg, Brussels and Luxembourg jointly
Brussels
There is no official seat

questions.question: Members of the European Parliament sit in the chamber according to:

answers.label: Their political affiliation
Their election results
Their nationality
Their result in the EU elections

questions.question: The European Parliament elections are held every 5 years

answers.label: Half the term, i
The same duration, 5 years
It is negotiated at the start of the mandate
Two-and-a-half years, which cannot be renewed

questions.question: In the Special Legislative Procedure, for legislative and non-legislative proposals, the consent of the EU Parliament is required:

answers.label: For discrimination, international agreements, Article 7, EU accession and withdrawal
Exclusively for Article 7 (Rule of Law) and Article 50 (withdrawal from the EU) procedures
In all cases
When it is invited to participate in the proce dure by the other institutions

questions.question: Which of the following make up EU primary law?

answers.label: EU Treaties
All legislative acts
Regulations, directives, decisions, recommendations and opinions
EU directives and regulations

questions.question: Which statement is true about EU regulations?

answers.label: Regulations are of general application, legally binding, and apply immediately in member states
Regulations allow member states to determine how they transpose the law into their national legislation
Regulations are primary legislation of the EU
Regulations are legally binding and have one specific addressee

questions.question: What is the process of transposition?

answers.label: It is the incorporation of EU directives into member states’ national legislation
It is a necessary process for EU regulations and decisions, since they are not directly applicable
It is a voluntary process from member states, without a specific deadline
It is not a compulsory process and the Commission cannot act if it is not carried out by a member state

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of Delegated Acts?

answers.label: They allow the Commission to act swiftly, to amend certain non-essential elements of laws
They enter into force even if the EU Parliament and Council object, so the Commission has full powers
They are used in slow procedures to accelerate the negotiations
They allow member states to immediately modify EU legislation and adapt it to national legislation

questions.question: Delegated Acts are typically used in cases such as:

answers.label: When legislative acts need to be adapted regularly, in line with scientific and technical progress
In the case of directives and regulations, since they apply immediately in member states
In the case of laws to combat discrimination, to protect the most vulnerable
In budgetary procedures, to accelerate the negotiations between institutions

questions.question: Implementing and Delegated Acts are:

answers.label: Non-legislative acts
Adopted under the Ordinary Legislative Procedure
Legislative acts
Regulations and Directives

questions.question: What is comitology?

answers.label: A series of procedures which give member states a say in Implementing and Delegated Acts
The process according to which legislative files are distributed between committees in the EU Parliament
Inter-parliamentary groups of MEPs who exchange on specific issues, such as animal welfare or LGBTI
The process by which the Council and EU Parliament can block a Delegated Act

questions.question: In the EU’s budgetary procedure, who is the budgetary authority?

answers.label: The European Parliament and Council
The EU Commission
DG BUDG
The Court of Auditors

questions.question: What is the relationship between the multi-annual financial framework (MFF) and the EU’s annual budget?

answers.label: The EU annual budget has to fit within the expenditure ceilings established in the MFF
There is no relationship, they are independent budgets
The MFF is made up of 7 annual budgets
The annual budget is always higher than the MFF in case there are expenditures that were not foreseen when designing the MFF

questions.question: How are the main EU competences divided?

answers.label: They are exclusive, shared or supporting
They are regular or special
This depends on the principle of subsidiarity
They are binding and non-binding

questions.question: Which institution adopts the final decision to conclude international agreements?

answers.label: The Council
The European Commission
It depends on the agreement - for trade it is the Commission, for others it is the Council
The EU Parliament

questions.question: Who attends COREPER II meetings?

answers.label: Permanent representatives of the Member States, who deal with General Foreign Affairs, conomic and Financial, and Justice and Home Affairs configurations of the Council

Permanent representatives of the member states who deal with Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs; Competitiveness (Internal Market, Industry, Research and Space); and Foreign Affairs
Deputy permanent representatives, preparing all Council configurations
Permanent representatives, MEPs and civil society representatives

questions.question: Who can chair COREPER meetings?

answers.label: They can be chaired by an elected chairperson, the rotating 6-month presidency representative, by a representative of the High Representative, or others
They are chaired by the president of the Council of the EU
An appointed specialist who heads the working party
They are always chaired by the delegate of the country holding the rotating 6-month presidency of the Council of the EU

questions.question: Who are members of the European Council?

answers.label: EU heads of state or government, and the Presidents of the European Council and the Commission
EU heads of state, exclusively
EU heads of state or government, and the Presidents of all the other EU institutions
EU heads of government, and external guests invited to their meetings

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Court of Justice of the EU?

answers.label: To ensure the uniform interpretation of EU law and that EU countries and institutions respect the law
To act as guardian of the EU Treaties
To support its 3 principal judges in deciding on cases brought before the Court
To provide a forum for judges from the 27 member states to formulate uniform legal standards in the member states

questions.question: What are the two main branches of the CJEU?

answers.label: The Court of Justice and the General Court
The Court of Auditors and the General Court
The Court of EU judges and the Specialised Court
The Specialised Court and the General Court

questions.question: The Court of Justice of the EU is responsible for dealing with:

answers.label: Actions brought by an EU country or the Commission against an EU country for infringing EU law
Individual or State applications of violations of the civil rights set out in the European Convention on Human Rights
Securing the right to life, respect for private life, and freedom of expression
Applying EU law to a dispute brought by a referring court

questions.question: What is the composition of the CJEU?

answers.label: 27 Judges and 11 Advocates General
27 Judges
28 Judges and 28 Counsels
It varies based on the case in question

questions.question: According to the fundamental principles laid down in Article 5 of the TEU, what does proportionality mean?

answers.label: That the content and scope of EU action may not go beyond what is necessary to achieve the objectives of the treaties

That for non-exclusive competences, the EU may act only if – and in so far as – the objective of a proposed action cannot be sufficiently achieved by the Member States, but could be better achieved at EU level
That the EU can only act in so far as member states have given it the power to do so
That the EU must always act proportionally to the issue at stake

questions.question: What is a pre-condition for the Council to be able to vote?

answers.label: A majority of its members must be present
The chair must be the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy
Member states must be represented by a State Secretary
The voting must be unanimous

questions.question: What is a Council configuration?

answers.label: It is each of the technical formations of ministers, of which there are 10 in total
A cross-sector grouping of ministers who meet informally to discuss overlapping issues such as health and employment
It is a type of meeting which is open to the public
It is a hierarchical system of Council formations which take individual decisions in the name of the Council

questions.question: How are EU agencies grouped?

answers.label: Decentralised agencies, executive agencies, EURATOM and EIT
Technical and scientific agencies, managerial agencies and Europol
Technical agencies, EURATOM and EESC and Committee of the Regions
Technical and scientific agencies, EESC and Committee of the Regions

questions.question: What is Europol?

answers.label: The European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation, based in The Hague
The European Police Office and Drugs Unit, based in Lyon
The International Criminal Police Organization, based in Vienna
The European Police Border and Coast Guard Agency, based in Warsaw

questions.question: What is the role of EFSA?

answers.label: It is a decentralised agency which provides scientific advice on food safety to the EU and member states
It is a part of the European Commission which provides advice on consumer protection in relation to food products
It is an agency with the aim of encouraging healthy eating by EU consumers
It is an agency with the power to control which food products go on the market in the EU

questions.question: What does EIGE stand for when talking about EU agencies?

answers.label: European Institute for Gender Equality
Economic and Investment Generation
European Initiative for Geothermal Energy
European Innovation Governmental Entity

questions.question: Who has responsibility for control of the EU’s external borders?

answers.label: Individual member states with an external border
Frontex
The EU Commission
It is a shared responsibility of the Commission and the member states

questions.question: What is the European Banking Authority (EBA)?

answers.label: An independent agency for regulation and supervision of the EU banking sector
A department within the European Central Bank which aims to create Single Rulebook in banking
A subsection of the Committee of European Banking Supervisors
A European system for financial supervision run by the European Systemic Risk Board

questions.question: HERA (Health Emergency Preparedness and Response Authority), created in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic, is:

answers.label: A new European Commission DirectorateGeneral
An EU Executive Agency
An independent body, similar to the EEAS
An EU decentralised agency

questions.question: Which are the EU’s common foreign and security policy agencies?

answers.label: European Defence Agency, European Union Institute for Security Studies, European Union Satellite Centre
EEAS, European Union Satellite Centre and Frontex
Frontex, the European Border and Coast Guard and the EEAS
European Atomic Energy Community, Euratom Supply Agency and EEAS

questions.question: What is the Green Deal and the Climate Law’s intermediate target of reducing net greenhouse gas emissions?

answers.label: By at least 55% by 2030, compared to 1990 levels
By at least 55% by 2050, compared to 1990 levels
By at least 55% by 2030, compared to 2000 levels
By at least 65% by 2050, compared to 1990 levels

questions.question: What is Fit for 55?

answers.label: A regulation setting stricter CO2 emission performance standards for new cars and vans
A directive setting stricter CO2 emission performance standards for old cars and vans
A strategy to achieve zero-emission mobility from old cars by 2055
A strategy to offset all emissions from vehicles

questions.question: Which of the following is a “Fit for 55” target?

answers.label: 100% CO2 emission reductions for both new cars and vans from 2035
55% CO2 emission reductions for old cars by 2030
55% CO2 emission reductions for new cars by 2030
100% CO2 emission reductions for both cars and vans from 2055

questions.question: Which economic sectors are included in the EU Green Deal?

answers.label: All sectors
Agriculture, energy and transport
Transport, finance, agriculture and energy
Transport, buildings, and agriculture

questions.question: Which of the following is an aim of the EU’s Better Regulation agenda?

answers.label: To make EU laws simpler and better
To remove the subsidiarity principle and take action in new areas
To involve citizens directly in decisionmaking via panels held in member states
To eliminate evidence-based policymaking to ensure legislation is passed more swiftly

questions.question: Better regulation, described as one of the most advanced regulatory approaches in the world, is an objective and responsibility of:

answers.label: All the EU institutions
The EU Commission
Local and regional authorities
The Council of the EU and the European Parliament

questions.question: What is the name of the portal which citizens can access to participate in the Better regulation agenda?

answers.label: Have your say
European Solidarity Corps
European Citizens Initiative
Consultation process

questions.question: What is Regulatory Fitness and Performance (REFIT) in relation to “Better regulation”?

answers.label: A programme to make EU law simpler as well as to reduce unnecessary costs of regulation
A programme to harmonise national legislation with EU legislation
A group of experts who check whether EU programmes are delivering the best results at minimum cost
A toolbox to help the EU Commission carry out impact assessments

questions.question: What is the internal market of the European Union?

answers.label: A single market which assures the free movement of goods, services, capital and persons
It is another name for the Schengen area
A market created in 1990 to exchange goods and services exclusively within the EU
A single market inside the EU which reduces tariffs and product inspections

questions.question: Which of these countries has full access to the internal market of the EU?

answers.label: Norway
Turkey
Switzerland
Canada

questions.question: What is the European Economic Area (EEA)?

answers.label: The extension of the EU internal market to EFTA countries
The EU market where good, services, capital and people can move freely
An area which applies different rules than the EU internal market
The border-free area which guarantees free movement to more than 400 million EU citizens

questions.question: What are the three pillars of the Digital Single Market?

answers.label: Access, environment, and economy and society
Sustainability, accessibility and consumer rights
Consumer rights, sustainability and environment
Access, consumer rights, and sustainability

questions.question: What is the power of the EU Commission under competition law?

answers.label: It monitors and investigates anti-competition practices, mergers and state aid
It can halt mergers in any circumstance, without the review of the European Courts because it is a Commission full competence
It intervenes in prices on the national markets, and can fine companies which do not comply
It cannot fine companies for using their bargaining power to impose certain conditions on competitors

questions.question: Which of the following are the pillars of competition law?

answers.label: The cartel prohibition, the abuse prohibition and merger control
Control of abuse of market power, and control of take-overs
Free market and use of mergers
Monitoring of anti-competitive practices

questions.question: What is the highest fine for infringement of EU competition law?

answers.label: 10% of a firm's annual turnover
5% of a company’s annual profit
5% of a company’s revenue
10% of a company’s monthly profit

questions.question: Who has the primary role in enforcing EU competition rules?

The Commission has sole responsibility for enforcing EU competition law
The Court of Justice of the EU
The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF)

Save the bees and farmers
End the cage age; on animal welfare

questions.question: What is Natura 2000?

questions.question: What is the aim of the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS)?

It is a component of the Common Agricultural Policy which aims to reduce emissions caused by livestock and crop farmers
It is a marketplace for emissions such as methane (CH4) and nitrous oxide (N2O), which enables the reduction of each participating company’s contribution towards climate change
It is a tool to equalise the price of carbon between domestic products and imports

The General Affairs Council usually decides by qualified majority voting

questions.question: Which of these cities are the EU accession criteria named after?

To make technology companies carry out risk assessments

35% of the total

questions.question: What is Horizon Europe?

The Marie Curie Agency for Investigation

questions.question: What is the European Innovation Council?

With National Recovery Plans
With the Digital Services Act
